s.text: And finally, the tabloids try to account for the end of soap star Susan Lucci's 18-time losing streak at the daytime Emmys.
The Enquirer suggests that "lonely" Joan was forced to make the call because she's been "abandoned" by her ex-husband.
As far as the numerologists are concerned, the other nominees shouldn't even have bothered to show up on Emmy night.
As far as the numerologists are concerned, the other nominees shouldn't even have bothered to show up on Emmy night.

We heartily recommend that she do whatever it takes to stay in the here and now, if only to avoid being included in the Enquirer 's "Scandals of the Century" double issue, which devotes an entire section ("The Quick and the Dead") to celebs cut down too soon.

We heartily recommend that she do whatever it takes to stay in the here and now, if only to avoid being included in the Enquirer 's "Scandals of the Century" double issue, which devotes an entire section ("The Quick and the Dead") to celebs cut down too soon.

They've revived an ailing dog ( ER 's Anthony Edwards), spent $700 nursing a rabbit back to health (actress Gretchen Mol), spearheaded efforts to free an inhumanely caged gorilla (Doris Day), and aided African elephants that suffer from "Floppy Trunk Syndrome," a malady that keeps the poor beasts from eating properly (Alicia Silverstone).

They've revived an ailing dog ( ER 's Anthony Edwards), spent $700 nursing a rabbit back to health (actress Gretchen Mol), spearheaded efforts to free an inhumanely caged gorilla (Doris Day), and aided African elephants that suffer from "Floppy Trunk Syndrome," a malady that keeps the poor beasts from eating properly (Alicia Silverstone).

They've revived an ailing dog ( ER 's Anthony Edwards), spent $700 nursing a rabbit back to health (actress Gretchen Mol), spearheaded efforts to free an inhumanely caged gorilla (Doris Day), and aided African elephants that suffer from "Floppy Trunk Syndrome," a malady that keeps the poor beasts from eating properly (Alicia Silverstone).

They've revived an ailing dog ( ER 's Anthony Edwards), spent $700 nursing a rabbit back to health (actress Gretchen Mol), spearheaded efforts to free an inhumanely caged gorilla (Doris Day), and aided African elephants that suffer from "Floppy Trunk Syndrome," a malady that keeps the poor beasts from eating properly (Alicia Silverstone).

The Globe , however, looks to the Fates to explain her win, calling in two numerologists to mull over Lucci's birth date, the cosmic significance of the year 1999, and the importance of the number 19 in her life.
Ted Kennedy's ex-wife, Joan, reportedly saved her own life by calling a taxi in the middle of a mild heart attack.
Hoping to keep the Grim Reaper at bay, O'Donnell is also said to be assiduously dieting and exercising.

One Globe photographer's prayers must have been answered when he followed Brooke Shields and new boyfriend Chris Henchy on what was supposed to be a simple exercise outing.
